conversation_overview.theme: Exploring values through Joe Edelman's theoretical framework and creating practical tools (values cards) to help people articulate their deepest values
conversation_overview.primary_focus: Understanding the distinction between instrumental choices (means to ends) and meaningful choices (expressions of core values), with application to workshop design and system prompts
conversation_overview.methodology_reference: Joe Edelman's 'Values, Preferences, Meaningful Choice' academic paper combined with emotions-to-values practice framework
conversation_overview.project_connection: Values Card Creation system - designing GPT-based tools to guide users in articulating and expressing their values

user_voice_extracts.content_summary: User shares Joe Edelman's academic paper 'Values, Preferences, Meaningful Choice' (190,974 characters) - a comprehensive theoretical framework distinguishing between revealed preferences and meaningful choices grounded in constitutive attentional policies (CAPs), plus a workshop practice framework for harvesting values from emotions
key_concepts_provided: Attentional Policies (APs) - frameworks we adopt for what to pay attention to in different contexts
Constitutive Attentional Policies (CAPs) - policies adopted not just for instrumental reasons but because they're constitutive of the kind of life we want
Meaningful Choice vs Revealed Preference - choices that express our values vs choices we make under constraint
Emotions as value signals - negative emotions point to blocked or unactualized values
Constitutive Judgements - decisions about what belongs together (part-whole claims) vs instrumental judgements (cost-benefit)
user_voice_extracts.practical_application: Designing workshop cards and system prompts to help people move from emotion recognition to values articulation

user_voice_extracts.content: This isn't thorough enough, I want a system prompt for a customGPT that includes all the steps needed and explains and gives some examples so it doesn't get confused and keeps asking till it gets it right and only when the user says sounds good does it make the card
user_voice_extracts.reveals_about_bilal: High standards for thoroughness; wants iterative refinement with user confirmation before finalization; prioritizes clarity and prevents premature closure; demonstrates systems thinking about how to guide others through complex processes
user_voice_extracts.decision_revealed: Rejected first assistant response as insufficient - wants more detailed, robust system prompt with built-in validation loops

about_values_and_meaningful_choice.source: Joe Edelman academic paper title (provided by user)
about_values_and_meaningful_choice.significance: The three-part framework that reframes how we think about what people actually want vs what they choose under constraint
about_values_and_meaningful_choice.relevance_to_bilal: Core intellectual framework Bilal is applying to design practical workshop tools

about_values_and_meaningful_choice.quote: I've decided to be more honest with friends. I recently opened up to a friend about a struggle I'm having. Since then, the relationship feels more intimate, and stronger; it's easier for me to think about what to say; my friend is unexpectedly helpful. But even if I knew my teams wouldn't last longer, or if those conversations were somehow blocked from happening, I'd still [choose this path].
about_values_and_meaningful_choice.source: Joe Edelman's personal narrative in Values paper (user input)
about_values_and_meaningful_choice.significance: Poetic illustration of constitutive choice - doing something not because of instrumental benefits but because it's constitutive of the kind of person/relationship one wants to be

about_values_and_meaningful_choice.quote: Attentional policies (APs) might account for much of what's called my 'personality': When making friends, am I cautious or bold? When considering a purchase, is my focus on price, quality, or durability? When speaking, do I try to be witty, precise, or down to earth? These may not just be 'character traits' I was born with, but policies I adopted, which work together for my way of life.
about_values_and_meaningful_choice.source: Joe Edelman's paper on attentional policies (user input)
about_values_and_meaningful_choice.significance: Reframes personality as deliberate policy choices rather than fixed traits - liberating and empowering insight
about_values_and_meaningful_choice.poetic_elements: Character as composition of chosen policies; personality as deliberate architecture

about_values_and_meaningful_choice.quote: If Janet's job search was about taking responsibility, she was guided by her values in searching, and we can take her choice as an expression of those values. If, however, her search was driven mainly by instrumental pressures like trying desperately to feed her family, her choice is less about values, and more about a tough situation. She's bucking to external pressure, caught in the system.
about_values_and_meaningful_choice.significance: Clarifies the crucial distinction between meaningful vs constrained choices - essential for understanding genuine values vs survival behaviors

about_values_and_meaningful_choice.quote: Constitutive judgements are cognitively efficient. Instead of asking each time we have an X whether we should also have a Y, we ask up-front if Xs and Ys belong together. If we think so, we put Ys in our Xs without considering each case.
about_values_and_meaningful_choice.source: Edelman's paper on bounded rationality and values (user input)
about_values_and_meaningful_choice.significance: Explains why values matter - they're cognitive shortcuts that encode our deepest commitments

about_emotions_as_value_indicators.quote: Your negative emotion pointing to the fact that this scenario is not part of your good life. Now it's time to meditate on what meaningful way of living you were not actualizing.
about_emotions_as_value_indicators.source: Emotions to Values Practice framework (user input)
about_emotions_as_value_indicators.significance: Elegant reframing of negative emotions as diagnostic tools - they reveal the gap between actual and valued life

about_emotions_as_value_indicators.quote: I was with my son at the grocery store. The lady in front of us was paying a rather large grocery bill with coins. It was taking forever. I felt frustrated. There was a tightness in my chest, and I was clenching my teeth. I just wanted to get out of there and get on with my day.
about_emotions_as_value_indicators.source: Emotions to Values Practice example (user input)
about_emotions_as_value_indicators.significance: Demonstrates how mundane frustration can be entry point to discovering core values - what was blocked in this moment?

about_design_and_system_prompts.quote: Ask the user for a brief, meaningful story or experience. Help them identify what truly mattered to them—something they were paying attention to that made the situation feel important.
about_design_and_system_prompts.source: Assistant response describing values card creation process
about_design_and_system_prompts.significance: Core methodology for values elicitation - finding the attentional focus in meaningful moments
about_design_and_system_prompts.relevance: Bilal's practical application of Edelman's theory

about_design_and_system_prompts.quote: Focus on criteria that are not merely instrumental—i.e., they reflect something the user wants to uphold, honor, or cherish for its own sake.
about_design_and_system_prompts.source: Values card creation prompt (assistant, influenced by Edelman framework)
about_design_and_system_prompts.significance: Critical filter to distinguish genuine values from surface preferences

about_design_and_system_prompts.quote: We also call this a 'source of meaning,' as it points towards a way of life you find meaningful.
about_design_and_system_prompts.significance: Connects concrete values articulation to larger life narrative - helps people see values as expressions of identity
